1.question: Which of the following is NOT a stated learning outcome for this lecture on map data visualization?

options.A: Describe spatial data for geographical visualization
options.B: Apply interactive map data visualizations
options.C: Understand how to map qualitative and quantitative data
options.D: Analyze historical map accuracy over time

2.question: What are the two fundamental requirements for map cosmetic elements mentioned in the document?

options.B: Title and legend
options.D: Scale indicator and north arrow

3.question: Which of the following is considered 'additional marginal information' for a map, according to the document?

options.B: Built-up areas
options.D: Road networks

4.question: Select all that are listed as 'additional marginal information' for maps.

options.B: User comments
options.D: Scale indicator

5.question: How do on-screen maps often address space constraints regarding marginal information?

options.A: Legends and titles are often available on demand
options.B: They provide marginal information only on print
options.D: They use smaller fonts for all text

6.question: What is the primary keyword for making maps 'Appealing' and increasing their communicative role?

options.B: Symmetry
options.D: Contrast

7.question: What is the main purpose of applying visual hierarchy in a map?

options.A: To ensure all information is perceived as equally important
options.B: To make the map look prettier
options.C: To reduce the file size of the map
options.D: To increase the communicative role by prioritizing information

options.A: It uses only symbols to represent data points
options.B: It uses colored or shaded areas to represent the magnitude of an attribute
options.C: It shows topographic features with elevation lines
options.D: It displays only roads and railways

9.question: What are the primary reasons for creating a choropleth map? Select all that apply.

options.B: Displaying variables' overall geographic pattern
options.C: Comparing multiple choropleth maps for variable distribution changes
options.D: Showing political boundaries exclusively

10.question: Which type of data is considered inappropriate for choropleth maps according to the document?

options.B: Continuous data not controlled by an enumeration unit
options.D: Population density data

11.question: What is the purpose of 'Data Classification' in choropleth maps?

options.B: To simplify generalized data for display on the map
options.C: To convert continuous data into discrete categories
options.D: To hide outliers in the dataset

12.question: What type of map projection is most appropriate for choropleth maps?

options.B: Equal area map projection
options.D: Conformal projection

13.question: In choropleth map symbolization, what color is generally reserved for the background or outlines?

options.B: Black
options.D: Light gray

14.question: According to the symbolization guidelines for choropleth maps, how should values be represented by color?

options.A: Any color can represent any value as long as a legend is present
options.B: Light gray for larger values, dark gray for smaller values
options.C: Black for smaller values, white for larger values
options.D: Black for larger values, light gray for smaller values

15.question: Which characteristic primarily distinguishes a 'Multimedia Map' from a standard 'On-Screen Map'?

options.A: Its integration of photography, sound, video, and animation
options.B: Its support for quick viewing only
options.D: Its ability to be printed on paper

16.question: What is a typical feature of an On-Screen Map related to data access?

options.B: A mouse click can link to tabular or other related map data
options.C: It cannot be presented on the World Wide Web
options.D: It requires specialized software to view

17.question: According to the document, what role does the World Wide Web commonly play in map data visualization?

options.B: It is only used for static map displays
options.C: It acts as a primary data collection tool
options.D: It's a common medium to present and distribute spatial data

18.question: How do geo-webservices contribute to map data visualization?

options.A: They provide interactive map views as an intermediate between data and web browser
options.B: They store map data exclusively offline
options.C: They replace all traditional mapping software
options.D: They only generate static map images

19.question: Which type of map allows users to interactively determine the contents by choosing data layers?

options.B: Thematic Map
options.D: Dynamic Map

20.question: What is a key characteristic of an 'Interactive Map' as described in the document?

options.A: It only allows zooming and panning
options.B: It's only for quick previews
options.C: It offers fully interactive presentation of 3D models
options.D: It cannot be linked to other data

21.question: What are the primary functions of a Static Map in map dissemination? Select all that apply.

options.A: To give web surfers a preview of products
options.B: To make maps more widely accessible
options.D: To provide fully interactive 3D models

22.question: According to the web maps classification, what are the two main categories of web maps?

options.B: Paper and Digital
options.D: Qualitative and Quantitative

23.question: Based on the web maps classification diagram, which of the following is true for both static and dynamic web maps?

options.A: They must always include an interactive interface
options.B: They are only suitable for multimedia integration
options.D: They can be 'view only'

24.question: Which statement best describes the efficiency of maps in data representation, according to the summary?

options.A: They are the most efficient and effective means to represent spatial information
options.B: They are only useful for simple datasets
options.C: They are primarily for aesthetic purposes
options.D: They are limited to showing qualitative data

25.question: What key aspect should guide map design?

options.A: How to say what to whom and if it is effective
options.B: Using only traditional cartographic symbols
options.D: Minimizing the number of data layers
